seg.seg: ... by performing ..., ... veneration to Bādhari the Brahmin.
... and they went away today. Whose ... serving as reward (?)
... and at last there is no property left for you. || In the Apratitu-
(lye) [tune] || ... (vehicles) adorned with decorations, cows, oxen (?), bulls, bu(ffalos)
... small cattle consisting of goats ..., seats, covers, clothes, decorations, food and drink
... in 100,000 ways. All things had gone away, being given as alms. The recipients, full of joy, went away
... || Being overjoyed, Bādhari the Brahmin, with his aged body (and) gleefully laughing
... Now I will, from this point on, with a carefree mind look forward only to (my) death.
Now I will, from this point on, with a clinging-free mind look forward only to (my) death.
... I will ... Then, with his hand raised, he says: Let us go, my sons! Support my a(ged body)
... The sun is going down. Let us too (go) away to our resting places, each to his own!
... the disciples supported Bādhari the Brahmin on both sides. Then Bādhari the Brahmin ... by the (sight) of his body
... (is worried in mind and says): Certainly you are disgusting (?). From my birth to the time when I was sixty years old
(... my physical strength, blood and bones were growing). From (when I was seventy years old) until I turned one hundred and twenty, day by day over the years
... old age took away from me strength and splendor of my body. ||
... I will transport (?) my own ... Oh, for the good luck ... with the good people

p.note: This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 10a16-11a(?). See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 38.

From the beginning of this line till line 4, Uy. is totally lost. We can find what follows in the Uy. now kept in Germany. Vide 49, Taf. 12. By the way, it must be pointed out of that Şinaki Tekin places this paragraph in a wrong place.
The line ends with the remnant of the name of a tune, to be completed as apratitu(lyenaṃ), cf. : a6, : a6, : b2, : a8, etc. Stanza of 4 x 25 (5/5/8/7) syllables.

opsi: new form, nom. pl., referring probably to a bovine, according to the Uy. text. ma(hirsāñä) “buffalos”, cf. the complete word in : a4; according to the context, it must be some kind of ox, “bos Indicus” in that case.

śoś, apparently nom. pl. here, elsewhere obl. pl. (cf. § 202), designates some small cattle; “sheep” is not at all certain. The preceding word is an epithet, nom. pl. masculine of an adjective *āṣi, derivative of ās “goat”, cf. the parallel adjective TB aṣiye (165). For āsāṇi cf. Skt. āsanā- ‘seat’.
dakṣinaki: So to be restored, cf. : b5; nom. pl. of dakṣinak, borrowed from Skt. dakṣinaka- = dakṣiṇīya- “worthy of gift”.
kapśiññis: completed according to MaitrHami 1, 10 b24-25 (cf. 18).
ṣālypu, new form, precise meaning unknown, cf. ṣālypi in : b2; translated according to MaitrHami 1, 10 b26 (cf. 18).

ynāsmār: it is also possible to read ytāsmār, but the 1. sg. med. prs. of the verb yät-, yat- “to decorate” is ytäsmār (see 129) and the meaning does not fit the context. In that case, if one tries to keep the reading ynāsmār, this form would belong to the verb yā- “to transport”, and the formation would follow the pattern of the verbs of movement, cf. *käl-nāsk- (> B källāṣṣäṃ) for the verb käl- “to bring”.
ynāsmār is the last word of the second pāda of a stanza which follows probably a pattern of 4 x 14 (7/7) syllables.
